citation.article-title: Thermoanaerobacter ethanolicus gen. nov., spec. nov., a new, extreme thermophilic, anaerobic bacterium.

p.s: Description of Thermoanaerobacter ethanolicus sp. nov.
Thermoanaerobacter ethanolicus (e.tha.no.li.cus. IVS.n. ethanol, corresponding alcohol of ethane (ethane + ol) M. L. masc. adj. ethanolicus, indicating the production of ethanol)
Morphology.

Rods, 0.3-0.8μm by 4-8μm in the early logarithmic growth phase; in later growth phases, cell shape varies from chains of coccoid cells (0.8 - 1.5 μm in diameter) to long filamentous cells (up to 100μm in length) which often divide by constriction to form chains of bacteria with differing cell lengths.
Uneven division is common.
Cells in the late logarithmic growth phase frequently form protuberances, blebs, or spheroplast-like forms; no heat-stable endospores observed.
One to twelve peritrichous flagella (up to 50 μm in length and 150-170 Å thick) which are commonly lost during the late logarithmic stage of growth; 4-8pili (about 50Å thick).
Colony Morphology.
Deep agar (2%; 60° colonies, 0.5-1 mm in diameter, lenticular, and white which can become dark brown in older cultures; no extractable pigment observed.
Surface colonies, 2-4 mm in diameter, smooth, white, round to irregular and flat after 50 h growth.
Physiology.
Chemoorganotroph, anaerobe.
Growth occurs between 37 and 78°C and from pH 4.4-9.9.
Utilizes various hexoses, ribose, xylose, cellobiose, sucrose, starch;inhibited by chloramphenicol, and Polymycin B.
Fermentation end products: From hexoses and starch mainly ethanol and CO2 with a minor production of lactate and acetate.
G + C Guanine Plus Cytosine Content of the DNA.
Between 37 and 39 mol%, determined by buoyant density measurements and around 32 mol% by the thermal denaturation method.
Habitat.
Alkaline and slightly acidic hot springs in Yellowstone National Park, WY, USA.
Type Strain. Thermoanaerobacter ethanolicus JW 200 (ATCC 31550).
